body:
We can keep this as an WIP pr, and you can keep developing as you go and continue the codereview. 

It is usually a good practice to merge when there is a complete set of changes that justifies the change

One of the thing we need to be careful with is the naming and API convention of the operators. I.e. we hope to introduce standard API when make sense and refer back to common packages.

@winstywang @zhreshold can you provide suggestions on the possible API naming convention?
Will do, let me figure out some related projects first

I have seen duplicate or similar operator names across different papers. This is fine in their original implementation, which however will introduce confusion if we put them in the same namespace. 
I guess it's much clearer to separate them into different package names if they are specific to some implementation. 
e.g.
```
topi.vision.yolo2.region
topi.vision.reorg
```
I agree that it is helpful to put the package specific implementations into specific namespaces like ```topi.vision.yolo2``` and pull common ones into ```topi.vision```

@PariksheetPinjari909 You don't need softmax3d. Current softmax implementation in master already handles arbitrary dimension inputs.

You should rebase against master, if you haven't.
@tqchen Sorry to hassle you but could this be reviewed again? I think the issues raised should all be addressed. Let me know if there's anything that needs fixing
just get back from a conference trip, on my todo list
Ah no problem, I just wondered if it had got lost somehow. No rush!

I didn't understand "but we need to use compute at at the inner most level to do so." Can you give an example?
Do you intend to work on fully supporting reduction in non-root node? I found it very beneficial when it gets to representing complicated data layouts.

I see what you mean. Is there any motivation for supporting such computation pattern? A workaround would be creating two stages, one that does local reduction over a few axis, and then reduce the result(this is the same artifact as rfactor).

Then using ```compute_at``` to move things around into the reduction axis(so that dependency inference will only realize part of the result at each iteration)
This layout is not used in any places so far, but serves as a good reference on how to implement the batched GPU kernel

motivation: let's say we have a matmul (C=A*B) and we want to bring a tile of A and a tile of B into from global to local, compute a partial result for a tile of C in local and accumulate it back in global.

In the workaround you explain, you still need to temporarily store a number of partial results (the number depends on how you split the reduction axis). Wouldn't that increase the memory requirement of the resulting code?
in that workaround, you pay one additional local memory equal to  tile size. This is invariant to reduction axis. Because you are computing inside the reduction axis
@sxjscience are you interested in making one?
when you get a NodeHandle in front end, you should always call NodeFree to free it when it is no longer needed. So for instance, we should free the handle returned by TVMNodeGetAttr

This can be safely ignored and may happen when you place a function at the root module scope. Could have things to do with static destruction.

Try to mark the global scope function by setting f.is_global =True so the free is not triggered.

I checked your example again can see what you mean by it is helpful to do so. The main problem here, though is that inline the reduction makes the reduction stage not schedulable, which is not intended behavior.

If there is a benefit of introducing such notation, we can try to form a proposal and do it. The current limitation mainly has to do with current prioritization of the project
closing for now as @yidawang 's answer might be the case, can reopen and investigate later

The example above is a piece of a real project I'm working on. I'm currently working around the limitation by doing the inlining manually which makes both the algorithm and the schedule more complicated and error-prone. In fact, during the manual inlining, I made a few mistakes that I found hard to debug and fix.
If there is anything I can help with, please let me know.

Can you give a concrete description of what do you expect when you inline the reduction?

- What are the IR looks like after we do the inline
- Can we schedule the reduction
OK. Thanks for the review. Im reworking on these comments.. will commit soon.
SO basically TVW will be a generic tensorrt, looking forward to see the new version
I don't know what the 'best' way to do this is, but you could have the RNN cell's new updated hidden state as an output to your computation so you can feed that in on the next time step

Something I forgot to mention: In the python code above, my schedule with and without inlining is trivial. In my real problem, I need to define a fairly complicated schedule which become even more complicated when I do the manual inlining because I need to modify the schedule accordingly.
see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/topi/recipe/rnn for some recipe
BTW, since this is a community project, you do not have to specifically at me to ask questions :)

I get what you mean. This can indeed be helpful. What you want is more than the semantics of "inline". By default, inline will place the computation at the inline location but we will only be able to schedule the final spatial axis. What you want is to "inheritate" the reduction axis as well into the target stage.

What you want is along the direction of "dataflow rewriting". Which we already have in cases like rfactor and cache_write(now you can reorder and split axis of tensor, before you cache write and the cached data layout will change accordingly). 

As a community project, we want to evolve the direction according to the need and use-cases community members.  So we are definitely welcoming proposals of new schedule primitives like this kind.
TVM uses a cross compiler. For android, you will need to download specific OpenCL library from the vendor or find it in your phone.
please rebase against master

OK, this makes sense.  In particular, the address returned for the variable 'n', which is represented above 3 different times is different for each time: 
* the call to (variable "n"): `0x7f72846d3000`
* the shape of the placeholder: `0x7f72847000a0`
* the shape of placeholder.op: `0x7f72840c02d0`

Thus, in this instance, the logical variable 'n' would be freed 3 times from the binding code.

If this is an accurate understanding, do you mind if I close this issue?

@tqchen  
phone libOpenCl.so  is not compatible when we are trying to compile tvm with phone libOpenCl.so. So couldn't figure to resolve this problem.
You don't have to build tvm itself with OpenCL library on phone. Instead, try link the final of compiled library to the phone OpenCL
Yes, please go ahead and close the issue

@tqchen 

am facing above error which i mentioned in first post of this thread.
[here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/apps/android_rpc/tests/android_rpc_test.py))
`f = tvm.build(s, [A, B], "opencl", target_host=target, name="myadd")`

why this depend on OpenCl device while building on respective target? if in case depend where to configure to resolve this problem?
it is fine to build your host code without opencl support, by setting USE_OPENCL=0 while still being able to cross compile to opencl
The storage scope of `C.local.rf` is `global` while that of `C.local` is `local`. Is that by design or is it a bug? I expected their storage scopes to be the same. Any ideas @tqchen?

Some thoughts on how we can support target context. I think the Target context query TLS should belong to tvm::Target . 

Instead of using setter getter, the target can be supported via scoping backed by a stack in TLS, which looks like ```Target::EnterTargetScope(target); Target::ExitTargetScope()```.

We can have RAII style version of scoping. Like
```
tvm::TargetContext ctx(target);
```

Which set target at construction time, and call Exit at destructor

There are two part of code

- The compiler stack: runs on your desktop, this can be built using USE_OPENCL=0
- The cross compiled library: runs on your phone, this must be built with USE_OPENCL=1, and link to proper opencl library on your phone
We can change this behavior by setting the scope to be the same. The scope can be changed by set_scope later

In general,  #892 is mostly ready, except for the target scoping system. We can paste in example code in this issue and discuss what can be improved. These examples can eventually go into the tutorials
Do you mind if I close this issue?  I am having some success with the javacpp bindings I was able to generate and I think that perhaps I would just like some time to proof out this pathway.

Should the python lib share the same underlying context? ie. should `tvm.target.current_target` `Target.__enter__` and `Target.__exit__` call into C++ to get, push and pop the context respectively? Or should the python retain a separate stack?

EDIT: got confused between Target and BuildConfig. Extra paragraph removed.
Ideally we would love them to be the same, so the interpolation happens.
@alex-weaver I will have multiple RNN Cells with different output size.. so its little difficult to keep track of all the outputs, again feeding at input..
what is  global/shared/local cache?  if i use global, the values will be preserved for the entire lifespan?
turns out the new way(Capsule) of handling extern type was also not good for the current way of handling NNVM, going to revert this PR for now to the old mode
MXNet side of PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/9880
You can ignore cat.bin as that is the image data. You can simply create your own TVMArray in java and feed it to TVM

This might happen, for example, if you include a header file in two places which contains functions that are not inlined. Closing this for now as we cannot offer more evidence toward this and seems it do not correspond to a problem on TVM side.
supported by #895

This is a restriction on the language, maybe we should have more clear error messages. They are not supported because we do not yet have semantics for these operations.

If we have a proposal on the expected semantics in a new issue, and provide examples, we can enhance the language to make it happen

the memory scope only has things to do with their location on thread scope. We do support multiple input and states in the scan operator, which gives the lstm example [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/topi/recipe/rnn)
closing due to inactivity and seems @yajiedesign provided a sensible answer, feel free to reopen when necessary

Ok, just to make sure I understand, this will just affect the api used inside the python target.generic_func ?
So the api used to register functions on both the python and c++ side will remain the same, but internally target.generic_func will keep a reference to the GenericFunc node instead of keeping a reference to the func_name of the default function?
yes, in python side we can just get a generic func object that contains register and is callable. Using string as key is always fragile since there can be duplication in names
@tqchen The example in `apps/sgx` should work now. Please let me know what you think. If it's to your liking, I'll tidy things up and add some docs!

In general, it looks good. To make the code style in apps/sgx also consistent with Google C style used in the rest of the project, let us change the suffix from cpp to cc, unless there is a code style culture for SGX that suggest the other way.

re: the failing tests, any tips? they work fine on my machine, so it's tough to figure out how (whether?) to fix them.

Otherwise, I'll have the PR spiffied up and ready to go by tomorrow.

OK,  but they will still *have* a string key to go into the dmlc::registry? This allows python to use schedules defined in C++, and provides a mechanism for nnvm to look up schedules
EDIT: I mean the GenericFunc internal registry, since it doesn't use dmlc::Registry

Any idea why this error is happenning while executing matexp.py?  
The same script was running before and now im getting this error.

`  File "matexp.py", line 152, in <module>
    rnn_matexp()
  File "matexp.py", line 149, in rnn_matexp
    check_device("cuda")
  File "matexp.py", line 117, in check_device
    f = tvm.build(s, [s_scan, Whh], target)

  File "/home/siju/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tvm-0.2.0-py3.6-linux-x86_64.egg/tvm/codegen.py", line 20, in build_module

  File "/home/siju/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tvm-0.2.0-py3.6-linux-x86_64.egg/tvm/_ffi/function.py", line 255, in my_api_func

`
look at the error message, it says nvcc not available, put cuda bin to your path

cuda/bin path is already given as part of make/config.mk
the other examples can run fine (the ones in tutorials folder).. except matexp.py
```

nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2016 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Tue_Jan_10_13:22:03_CST_2017
Cuda compilation tools, release 8.0, V8.0.61

siju@siju-DAEMON:~/D/Community/nnvm/tvm/topi/recipe/rnn$
```

Ok the python registration is updated to use a reference to a GenericFunc node instead of repeatedly using func_name
Okay, the code is now ready for a proper review! At your leisure.

This is the runtime(nvcc compiler) that requires the cuda path, you need to do that by 
```bash
export PATH=${PATH}:/usr/local/cuda/bin
```
yes, we can still have a string key based registry for generic func
:+1:  Yeah. Thanks a lot. I forgot to set this path after rebooting.
It is likely that we could make use of SystemLib option, instead of creating the dll library and preload them into files

Specifically, we could try to export the dependent binaries by PackImportToC and use emcc to compile and link everything as static library, which put them into js. Or simply call module.export_library by using emcc as a linker.
see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/module.py#L94

I'm currently making the host library syslib, and dynamically load js device library.

Let me try export_library.

The cache_write is equivalent to directly create a stage 

```python
# result of cache local
index, value = topi.argmax(input)
# copy stage
data_global = tvm.compute(data_red_local[0].shape, 
      lambda *i: (index(*i), value(*i)))
```

The ideal use case should be like

```python
mod.export_library(lib_path, emcc.create_js, **options)
```

seems to be a specific error due to bracket not supported by g++ change that line to 
```
 const std::unordered_set<std::string>& libs = std::unordered_set<std::string>()
```

should solve the problem
can you submit a PR to TVM to fix this?
http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/optimize/opt_gemm.html#vectorization

please close this  for now as the original issue has been answered, we prefer to aggressively close issues and open new ones when necessary so there is minimum amount of issues, and the community won't forget about them
cc @zhreshold can you do a round of review? We also need to suggest a possible GPU schedule to get this merged.

Update: I tried `export_library`, and it turns out you need some tweaks so I ended up pulling out the logic and modified a bit.

Now I'm having a new problem. At module loading time we
- Statically initialize a variable by [calling `TVMBackendRegisterSystemLibSymbol`](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/codegen/codegen.cc#L83), which ...
- [Calls `ImportModuleBlob`](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/system_lib_module.cc#L41), which ...
- Is responsible for loading the OpenGL device library binary, which ...
- Is achieved by calling `module.load_opengl`, which ...
- Cannot be found.

My theory is that the registry `module.load_opengl` hasn't been initialized. This is due to the fact that you can't really control the order of static variable initialization.

Good point, this is something we should fix. We can fix the logic by add a deferred list of module blob we need to import to a vector, and every time we call GetFunction, do the import if there is a deferred list
Thanks for the fix
Update: succeeded. Let me update the PR.
Thanks very much!! I tried with set_scope, and simulate cache_write successfully. So should we  wrapped the them together?
We can enhance cache_write to support such case of multiple outputs
Updated.
Great, this is merged

here's how I construct the network:
def op_to_test(layout):
    inputs = sym.Variable("data")
    outputs = sym.conv2d_transpose(data=inputs,channels=1,groups=1,
                                  kernel_size=(4,4),strides=(2,2),
                                  padding=(1,1),use_bias=False,
                                  layout=layout,name='test_op')
    return outputs

here's how I compile it:
    test_op = op_to_test("NCHW")
    with nnvm.compiler.build_config(opt_level=3):
        with tvm.build_config(auto_unroll_max_step=128,
                              auto_unroll_max_depth=4,
                              unroll_explicit=False,
                              double_buffer_split_loop=50):
            graph_net, lib, params = nnvm.compiler.build(test_op, 
                                target='cuda', shape={"data":data_shape}, 
                                dtype="float32",params=params)
@PariksheetPinjari909 can you please update according to the review comments? Thanks!

For now we can do things like
```
tvm.gpu(i).exist
```

to check if such device exist, a query listing API would have been better, but this one also serves most of the purposes.
